awd_titl_txt: Quantum Feedback, Closed-Loop Magnetometry, and Quantum Nonlinear Dynamics at the Quantum/Classical Boundary
awd_abstract_narration:
This work aims to help lay the foundation for new technologies that use quantum physics to out-perform conventional non-quantum devices, a situation referred to as "quantum supremacy". The first goal of this project is to borrow an element of conventional engineering known as the feedback loop (familiar from, e. g., the cruise control in a car), apply it to a manifestly quantum object (here, a collection of atoms trapped by a laser beam), and show that "quantum feedback" can greatly improve the sensitivity, speed, and reliability of magnetic sensors. From a basic science perspective, feedback control involves measurement and corrective action (e. g., measuring the speed of a car and increasing/decreasing engine power to keep the speed of the car reliably constant). In the quantum realm, this interplay between measurement and correction is fundamentally limited by the quantum uncertainty principle, according to which measurement also causes disturbance, which then limits the accuracy of the correction.  The second goal of this project is to study this measurement/disturbance tradeoff in quantum feedback when controlling a physical system (again, atoms in a laser trap) subject to chaos, a scenario that is challenging even in conventional engineering.

A recurrent theme in quantum metrology has been the use of continuous quantum measurement and feedback to construct adaptive measurement strategies that outperform their open-loop equivalents. One good example is the pioneering work of Wiseman on adaptive measurement strategies for homodyne phase estimation, along with related strategies for coherent state discrimination. In the early 2000's, Mabuchi and co-workers developed the theoretical framework for closed-loop strategies that use optical dispersive quantum nondemolition (QND) measurements and real-time feedback to create spin squeezing and perform magnetometry below the standard quantum limit (SQL), but were unable to implement these ideas in practice.  The main objective of this project is to show that quantum feedback and closed-loop control of collective atomic spins is an experimentally viable idea with applications in quantum metrology and quantum simulation. Over the past few years the Principal Investigator has systematically solved many of the problems that plagued the early work, allowing significant deterministic squeezing of the collective angular momentum of an atomic ensemble, as well as a proof-of-principle demonstration of closed-loop control and magnetometry below the SQL. Building on these accomplishments, the goals of this project are (i) Further development of closed-loop magnetometry, and (ii) Exploration of a novel type of quantum nonlinear dynamics where the evolution of a quantum system is conditioned on the outcome of a time-continuous QND measurement. The latter provides an attractive platform for fundamental studies of the information gain/disturbance tradeoffs involved in real-time quantum feedback.  It also provides access to new regimes of quantum simulation, and an opportunity to study long-standing issues related to quantum-classical correspondence in chaotic systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

 

Looking broadly at modern technology, one feature is nearly universal: the use of feed-back control. In a negative feedback loop a "controller" (typically a microprocessor) measures what the system is doing and then takes corrective action if it drifts away from the desired setpoint. At the basic level this is how the cruise control in a car works. Interestingly, if one tries to extend feedback control to quantum objects, new limits arise because measurement itself adds noise in the feedback loop. This is a manifestation of quantum uncertainty relations that limit us from, for example, knowing both position and momentum of an object at the same time. Surprisingly, there are workarounds - if the quantum measurement is done slowly and in a time-continuous fashion, one can shunt noise from the measurement into one degree of freedom and leaving another nearly noise free. This is the idea behind squeezing, which has been used to improve performance ranging from atomic clocks to the massive mirrors in LIGO. Thus, since the early 2000's, experiments across a huge range of quantum technologies have seen advantages in sensor performance, from a few dB to more than 20db relative to the Standard Quantum Limit (SQL). For practical purposes the latter can be considered as the best one can do without playing quantum "tricks".

 

The Primary focus of this Project has been closed-loop control of quantum objects. The work has shown that feedback control is not restricted to classical objects, and that also in the quantum regime it can be powerful tool for control of quantum systems large and small. A separate but related theme has been the use of continuous quantum measurement and feedback to construct adaptive measurement strategies that outperform their open-loop equivalents. Unfortunately, some of the early work in this area proved impossible to replicate, leading to retraction of high-profile papers and a general, if temporary, retreat from the field. Thus, a second goal of the Project has been to show that quantum feedback and closed-loop control can in indeed be applied to large collections of atomic spins. Over the course of the project the PI and co-workers have systematically addressed all of the problems that plagued the early work, and this has led to substantial squeezing of collective spins with angular momenta of ~ 106 hbar. Based on these accomplishments, the project has demonstrated the use of in-loop spin squeezing in an atomic magnetometer, leading to a magnetic field sensitivity approximately 8dB below the Standard Quantum Limit (SQL).

 

The secondary focus of the Project has quantum nonlinear dynamics, an area of enormous current interest in the field of quantum many body physics and quantum simulation. As it has pushed into new regimes, the Project has explored complex nonlinear dynamics of open, continuously measured quantum systems near the quantum-classical boundary, and thereby provided new insights into the kind of physics that can be reliably simulated and observed.

 

The first example is a mean-field simulation of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking in the so-called Lipkin-Meshkov-Glick (LMG) model, a popular model system for the study of phase transitions in quantum many body systems. Notably, the symmetry breaking is driven by quantum noise from the measurement and would not happen without it. Furthermore, the measurement record makes it possible to observe the act of symmetry breaking in real time.

 

Most recently, the PI and co-workers have taken steps to implement a popular model system for the study of quantum chaos, the so-called Quantum Kicked Top (QKT).  The emergence of chaos in the dynamics of meso- and macroscopic quantum systems remains an important problem in the study of correspondence and the quantum/classical transition. The consensus is that classical chaos will emerge only in open quantum systems, i. e. systems that are coupled either to a decohering environment, or to a meter that performs continuous weak measurements of one or more system observables.  As in the example above (the LMG model), the measurement record constitutes a quantum trajectory, which can approach that of the corresponding classical system and thereby show hypersensitivity to initial conditions with the appropriate Lyapunov exponent. This final objective is currently pursued by the one PhD student still doing active research on the Project. It remains to be seen what, if anything, will come from it.

 

Broad Impact

This Project has provided research topics and financial support to two PhD students, one of which has graduated and is now employed in the private sector. Through collaboration with the Center for Quantum Information and Control, an NSF funded FRHTP Center, the Project has also enriched the range of work performed by PhD students and postdocs from its ranks. As a result, the Project has led to 3 publications in peer reviewed journals, all with mixed authorship from both the Project and from the FRHTP.
